Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: The station is set to lock its doors in ten minutes.
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was about to step out the door. It was a message from Mom: “Haven’t heard from you all weekend. Everything okay?” I glanced at the clock—ten minutes until the polling station closed. I’d promised myself I wouldn’t miss voting this year, not after all the debates and discussions I’d had with friends about how important it was. But Mom’s texts always carried a weight; she worried if I didn’t check in, and I knew she’d be up all night if I didn’t reply. My thumb hovered over the screen, torn between dashing out the door to make it in time and sitting down to send a thoughtful reply. I could feel the pressure building in my chest—my parents expected me to stay connected, to reassure them, but my sense of civic duty was just as strong. The minutes ticked by, and I stood frozen, caught between being a good daughter and a responsible voter, wishing I could be both at once.
